I hear a rattle when I put my car into drive or reverse, when starting cold. It's an 8th gen accord, 4cil, auto transmisison. Fluid is fine.

It makes no abnormal sounds whatsoever after everything is warmed up, and drives fine. Should I worry, or have this checked?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26115891
Engine or trans mount or both

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26115891
Have your exhaust J-pipe hanger bushing inspected, often times on K24 Accords, that insulator rubber rots away, and then the exhaust system sits against the subframe when the car is put into reverse and drive, I spent hundreds of dollars replacing motor mounts chasing this issue, and it ended up being an hour of labor and a $30 part.

>>26115914
Also this, but inspect that J pipe insulator first, K24 Accords and Acuras can be real dumb sometimes, I've seen guys replace all four struts on their TSX chasing a clunking sound, and it ended up being a trans mount.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
In 1982, Ford launched a sporty companion car to its new Escort subcompact lineup, the Ford EXP and Mercury LN7. These small FWD two seaters were meant to compete with the Dodge 024 and assorted Japanese sporty coupes. However it proved faster than it looked as the EXP managed to weigh 200 pounds more than a standard Escort 2 door hatchback and had the same underwhelming 1.6L engine, mated with a standard 4-speed manual gearbox. A 5-speed was optional, and a 3-speed automatic. Over 48,000 EXPs were moved the first year but sales tapered after that. Several improvements by 1984 included a turbo version of the standard 1.6L engine.

The EXP was dropped for the 1985 model year and then brought back halfway through as 1985-1/2 models bearing Ford's new "aero" design motif. Some 83,000 of these were sold through the 1988 MY after which it was dropped due to hikes on two seater insurance rates. The Gen 2 EXP had the newer, larger 1.9L Escort engine and by the end, sequential multiport fuel injection.

The LN-7 was shorter-lived; a respectable 49,000 of the 1982 models (edging the EXP slightly) gave way to a meager 4,528 of the 1983 models after which the plug was pulled. Customer surveys found that the typical small sporty car buyer was not as likely to visit a Mercury-Lincoln showroom--similar issues plagued the Mercury Capri during this period.

Torque and HP varied wildly over the years.

My Bronco was pretty high with the options list, including the push bumper, captain's chairs, 29" tires (vs the stock 27") and 3.50 gears so it's likely it was originally 115-120 hp which is still pathetic for a 4x4 weighing in at over 2 tons.

But you still drank too much of the kool-aid.
It was a good design for a base model engine offering but it only came with a 1 barrel until EFI, which itself had major hesitation issues (you could slam the gas pedal to floor and take your foot off the pedal before it revved).

The "6=8" crowd tout its aftermarket support but in reality there's only 2 worthwhile intakes for a 4 barrel and for a header you're looking at chinesium grade components or modifying a setup from the EFI models.

Meanwhile aftermarket support for the windsor family is one of the largest available. There's 50 different intakes depending on applications and virtually every cam profile has been dyno'd. The only reason to stick with a 300 is nostalgia or a matching numbers build. A 351w outperforms it across the entire rpm range.

threads.com:
Why are classic Japanese and European performance cars more popular than the American ones? The Skyline GT-Rs have a legendary status even though the Corvette C4s would easily smoke it on the tracks at a lower price point. Performance wise the ZR1 had pretty much every supercar beaten in the early 90s. 911, NSX, Ferrari, Supra, Lotus, you name it, and I'm not only talking about straight line performance, it had superior turning and braking. And yet Corvettes especially C4 has virtually no cultural impact unlike those cars. R34s, NSXs, and Supras are the stars in so many movies and games while nobody cares about the Corvette. Skyline is known as the unbeaten godzilla while C4s are known as some outdated plastic car from the neon lit boomer era.

What went wrong? Not american btw.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26112372
The FRC looks a lot better in person, a lot of video games and scale models get the shape wrong and make it look worse than it does in real life. Finishing it with a small ducktail spoiler also helps a lot, too.

I went FRC because I didn't want the leaks aging coupes are known for due to people removing the roof and not being careful and tearing up the weather seal. The pre-Z06 FRC also comes with all base options so I dodged a lot of the annoying reliability issues with electronics the maxed-out cars have.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26112495
The FRC was used because it was the stiffest variant of the platform. That big hatch gave up some stiffness, as did the removable roof on the normal coupe.

The race car was a coupe because it was a heavily modified race car with a tube frame chassis underneath, so it didn't suffer the rigidity problems of the real coupe and the stretched glass gave better aero. The base coupe was also the standard offering, so of course they wanted to showcase that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26114696
interesting. if i were going to look at a 93 with 170k miles on it what should i immediately check for?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26114722
A rare 30 year old Infiniti with 170,000 miles what could possibly go wrong?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26114722

Make sure the engine sounds good, warm it up fully and make sure the transmission shifts quickly, and that there's lots of power between 4-7K rpm check the fluids, look for rust or messed with wiring. If it isnt really fast there's a chance its running 87 octane, there's a chance that It will never drive properly without a lot of work. Check heated seats, wipers, and all of that stuff, make sure the alternator can handle a full load and that its comfy. Old nissans tend to have leaky power steering which was never an issue on my J30s. But on every
Pathfinder. Feel for slop in the steering. Worn/ Blown shocks are normal for the age/miles but I drifted the shit out of my 2nd J30 and the handling got slightly sloppy by the time I sold it. Other than that see if there are service records, make sure the timing and other belts arent old. Fresh oil, atf and rear end oil. Once you get it, be careful. Take it on a gravel road and hoon a bit so that when you break it loose on a rainy corner you can whip it back in line without panicking.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: The redesigned 1986 GM E-body coupes proved a sorry case of poor product planning and the general disorder and chaos that afflicted the General throughout the 80s-early 90s. A good six inches shorter than the 79-85 generation and a couple hundred pounds lighter, they had been conceived during the turn of the decade energy crisis. Unfortunately by the time they got to showrooms, gas prices had fallen back to 1960s levels and the new E-bodies looked faintly comical with none of their predecessors' style or presence and they were derided in the automotive press as plastic toys and "Hot Wheels" cars. The initial Eldorados also had the troublesome Cadillac HT4100 V8, replaced by an improved version two years later. These ill-timed and unreliable luxury coupes failed to win over many import buyers and symbolized in many ways the troubled Roger Smith era at GM.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: What was the golden age of car design In your opinion? Post cars from the era you consider most aesthetically pleasant

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>26108943
The 1990s. There hasn't been a decade before or since that had just a complete mayhem approach to car design. It was that transitional period where the boxy-ness of the 80s still lingered but pure aerodynamics consideration hadn't taken complete control like in the 2000s.

I know people like to look at older cars as being "aesthetically pleasing" but they tend to only focus on the outliers the cars designed from beginning to end to be works of art. I think in the 90s alot of cars ended up like that un-intentionally. Certainly enough so that you can see a car from the 90s and not immediately think "oh that is so 90s" (unless it's painted teal, which is a dead giveaway), the same way you can look at a car from the 70s and think "oh that is something from the 70s".
